prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Measure CO(2-1) line fluxes for a sample of 4 AGNs at z~1.5 in the COSMOS field.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use 4 basebands in FDM with a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and a spectral resolution of ~27 km/s. We will apply spectral averaging in the data transfer of a factor of 16 (27 km/s), in order to reduce the data rate to values <6 MB/s.
The four Basebands have been arranged to cover almost the two full sidebands allowing us to observe the CO(2-1) for several objects with the same tuning and therefore saving time on overheads to maximize the scientific output of ALMA time.
We ask for a 1.6" resolution since the main goal of our project is to measure the total flux of the CO(2-1) line rather than resolving it and this set-up will give more flexibility while scheduling.

We estimated the CO luminosity from the total infrared luminosity(LIR) in the 8-1000micron range following the Genzel et al. (2010) relation for starbursting galaxies at z~1.5 which is appropriate for our sources that are mostly above the main-sequence of star-forming galaxies (Fig 1-right).
LIR is estimated from a direct fit to Herschel photometry. The CO line intensity S(CO) is calculated from L'(CO) according to Solomon & Vanden Bout (2005) assuming an expected FWHM of 400 km/s, which corresponds to the mean FWHM of the CO(2-10 line for the sample of inactive galaxies observed with PdBI by Tacconi et al. (2013) as well as for the quasars with measured CO(2-1) in the compilation by Carilli & Walter (2013).
A sensitivity of 0.190 mJy over a 130 km/s channel will assure a 5 sigma detection of the line for our faintest object in the sample (source X2072). For the brighter objects in the sample the line will be detected with a higher S/N (see Table 2).
The bandwidth of 130 km/s chosen for the sensitivity calculation will allow to sample a CO(2-1) of FWHM~400 km/s in a minimum of three spectral elements.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Measure CO(2-1) line fluxes for a sample of 4 AGNs at z~1.5 in the COSMOS field.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use 4 basebands in FDM with a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and a spectral resolution of ~25 km/s. We will apply spectral averaging in the data transfer of a factor of 16 (25 km/s), in order to reduce the data rate to values <6 MB/s.
The four Basebands have been arranged to cover almost the two full sidebands allowing us to observe the CO(2-1) for several objects with the same tuning and therefore saving time on overheads to maximize the scientific output of ALMA time.
We ask for a 1.6" resolution since the main goal of our project is to measure the total flux of the CO(2-1) line rather than resolving it and this set-up will give more flexibility while scheduling.

We estimated the CO luminosity from the total infrared luminosity(LIR) in the 8-1000micron range following the Genzel et al. (2010) relation for starbursting galaxies at z~1.5 which is appropriate for our sources that are mostly above the main-sequence of star-forming galaxies (Fig 1-right).
LIR is estimated from a direct fit to Herschel photometry. The CO line intensity S(CO) is calculated from L'(CO) according to Solomon & Vanden Bout (2005) assuming an expected FWHM of 400 km/s, which corresponds to the mean FWHM of the CO(2-10 line for the sample of inactive galaxies observed with PdBI by Tacconi et al. (2013) as well as for the quasars with measured CO(2-1) in the compilation by Carilli & Walter (2013).
A sensitivity of 0.190 mJy over a 130 km/s channel will assure a 5 sigma detection of the line for our faintest object in the sample (source X5321). For the brighter objects in the sample the line will be detected with a higher S/N (see Table 2).
The bandwidth of 130 km/s chosen for the sensitivity calculation will allow to sample a CO(2-1) of FWHM~400 km/s in a minimum of three spectral elements.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Measure CO(2-1) line fluxes for a sample of 4 AGNs at z~1.5 in the COSMOS field.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use 4 basebands in FDM with a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and a spectral resolution of ~24 km/s. We will apply spectral averaging in the data transfer of a factor of 16 (24 km/s), in order to reduce the data rate to values <6 MB/s.
The four Basebands have been arranged to cover almost the two full sidebands allowing us to observe the CO(2-1) for several objects with the same tuning and therefore saving time on overheads to maximize the scientific output of ALMA time.
We ask for a 1.6" resolution since the main goal of our project is to measure the total flux of the CO(2-1) line rather than resolving it and this set-up will give more flexibility while scheduling.

We estimated the CO luminosity from the total infrared luminosity(LIR) in the 8-1000micron range following the Genzel et al. (2010) relation for starbursting galaxies at z~1.5 which is appropriate for our sources that are mostly above the main-sequence of star-forming galaxies (Fig 1-right).
LIR is estimated from a direct fit to Herschel photometry. The CO line intensity S(CO) is calculated from L'(CO) according to Solomon & Vanden Bout (2005) assuming an expected FWHM of 400 km/s, which corresponds to the mean FWHM of the CO(2-10 line for the sample of inactive galaxies observed with PdBI by Tacconi et al. (2013) as well as for the quasars with measured CO(2-1) in the compilation by Carilli & Walter (2013).
A sensitivity of 0.200 mJy over a 130 km/s channel will assure a 5 sigma detection of the line for our faintest object in the sample (source X69). For the brighter objects in the sample the line will be detected with a higher S/N (see Table 2).
The bandwidth of 130 km/s chosen for the sensitivity calculation will allow to sample a CO(2-1) of FWHM~400 km/s in a minimum of three spectral elements.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
One prediction of the wind-model for AGN radiative feedback is the direct link between the mass outflow rate in the wind and the mass inflow rate towards the central black hole. If these outflows have an impact on the host galaxy star-formation this should be traced by the content of the molecular gas reservoir in the host galaxy. Previous studies of the molecular gas content of AGNs are limited to objects with high accretion rates. The main goal of this proposal is to characterize the cold gas content of the host galaxy as a function of the Eddington ratio.
This study will give us the possibility of testing the logic sequence: higher accretion rates -- more powerful AGN driven outflows -- higher impact on the gas reservoir of the host galaxy.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
